etymology.description: A line above another line -> indicates 'up'
etymology.interpretation: The character visually represents a line positioned above another, symbolizing upward direction or the concept of being 'on top.' This simplicity highlights its clear graphical indication of elevation or ascension.

examples.chinese: 鸟儿飞上树梢(鳥兒飛上樹梢)。
examples.english: The birds fly to the treetops.

examples.chinese: 他把梯子搭上(他把梯子搭上)，爬上屋顶(爬上屋頂)。
examples.pinyin: Tā bǎ tīzi dā shàng, pá shàng wūdǐng.
examples.english: He set the ladder up and climbed onto the roof.

examples.chinese: 太阳从东方升上天边(太陽從東方升上天邊)。
examples.pinyin: Tàiyáng cóng dōngfāng shēng shàng tiānbiān.
examples.english: The sun rises from the east and ascends to the horizon.
